atAGlance.mustRegister: People convicted of Vermont registrable offenses and people with comparable out-of-state, federal, or military convictions who live, work, or study in VT (see [13 V.S.A. §5407](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407) and definitions in [§5401](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05401)).
atAGlance.initialDeadline: Move-ins, workers, or students: register within 10 days of establishing presence; visitors: 10 consecutive days or 30 days per year triggers a duty (see [§5407(a)(1)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
atAGlance.verificationCadence: Annually (return verification within 10 days after birthday). Sexually Violent Predators verify every 90 days ([§5407(e)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
atAGlance.primaryMethod: Central registry via VCIC (mail/phone). Photo and fingerprints at VT State Police when instructed ([VCIC: Vermont registrants](https://vcic.vermont.gov/sor/vermont-registrants), [VCIC: out-of-state](https://vcic.vermont.gov/sor/out-of-state)).
topGotchas: Report address, employment, school, or legal name changes within 3 days; high-risk address changes within 36 hours ([§5407(d)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407), [§5411b(c)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05411b)).
Knowing failure to comply is a felony ([§5409](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05409)).
Not all registrants are on the public website; posting depends on offense/risk ([§5411a](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05411a)).

whoMustRegister: Adults convicted of listed sex offenses (for example, [§3252](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/72/03252) sexual assault; [§3253](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/72/03253) aggravated sexual assault; [§2601](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/67/02601) lewd and lascivious conduct; [§2602](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/67/02602) with a child; Chapter 64 child-exploitation) and comparable out-of-state, federal, or military convictions (see [§5401](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05401)). Move-ins, workers, and students from out of state must register ([§5407(a)(1)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)). Youth cases kept in juvenile court generally do not register.
deadlinesReporting: Initial report for out-of-state conviction moving to or working/studying in VT: within 10 days ([§5407(a)(1)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
Annual verification: sign and return within 10 days after birthday ([§5407(e)(1)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).

Changes (address, employment, post-secondary school, legal name): within 3 days; high-risk address change within 36 hours ([§5407(d)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407), [§5411b(c)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05411b)).
verificationInPerson: VCIC mails verification around birthday; registrant must sign and return within 10 days ([§5407(e)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
Sexually Violent Predators verify every 90 days ([§5407(e)(2)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
VCIC may require updated photo; photo and fingerprints are done at VT State Police when instructed ([VCIC out-of-state steps](https://vcic.vermont.gov/sor/out-of-state)).
residencyPresence: No statewide residency or loitering zones in statute. Individualized limits may be imposed by probation or parole while under supervision. Local ordinances are uncommon but check your municipality. State law itself does not impose buffer zones.
employmentEducationInternet: Report employment or post-secondary school changes within 3 days ([§5407(d)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
Public site does not display employer details; supervision may add job-specific limits case by case ([§5411a](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05411a)).
publicWebsiteExposure: Internet posting criteria are set by statute and the court; higher-risk and specified offenses are posted ([§5411a](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05411a)).
Public listing shows photo, offense, and town (not street address). Victim identity is never disclosed.
travelInterstate: Moving out of VT: notify VCIC and register in the new state within 3 days of establishing residence ([§5407(d)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
International travel: follow federal International Megan’s Law 21-day advance notice via your local registry (contact [VCIC](https://vcic.vermont.gov/sor) for VT procedure).
visitingTraveling: Visitors with out-of-state convictions must register if present 10 consecutive days or 30 days total in a year ([§5407(a)(1)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
Short hotel stays under these thresholds do not trigger VT registration; still follow your home state’s travel-notice rules.
Homeless or transient individuals must provide specific location details and follow VCIC check-in arrangements (see [VCIC guidance](https://vcic.vermont.gov/sor/out-of-state)).
complianceEnforcement: Knowing failure to comply is a felony: up to 2 years (first) or 5 years (subsequent) and fines; sentences can run consecutively ([§5409](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05409)).
reliefPaths: Standard registration term is 10 years after completion of sentence and supervision; certain offenses or designations are lifetime ([§5407(e)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
Lifetime registrants may petition after 10 years to end public posting if no longer high-risk ([§5411](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05411)).
specialPopulations: High-risk designation (DOC) increases duties; noncompliant high-risk have 30-day in-person check-ins and added requirements ([§5411b](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05411b), [§5411d](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05411d)).
Sexually Violent Predators verify quarterly and may face additional disclosure rules ([§5407(e)(2)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
costs: No routine state registration fee; local fingerprinting fees may apply (see [VCIC](https://vcic.vermont.gov/sor/out-of-state)).

newArrivalChecklist: Within 10 days of arrival to live, work, or study: contact VCIC and submit the packet ([§5407(a)(1)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407), [VCIC](https://vcic.vermont.gov/sor/out-of-state)).
Complete photo and fingerprints at VT State Police as directed.
Calendar your birthday-month verification and return it within 10 days ([§5407(e)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
movingOutChecklist: Notify VCIC of new address and departure date.
Register in your new state within 3 days of establishing residence ([§5407(d)](https://legislature.vermont.gov/statutes/section/13/167/05407)).
Confirm Vermont shows you as moved; keep dated proof.

summary: Expect a mailed verification each year; return it within 10 days. SVPs verify quarterly.
VCIC may ask for an updated photo and direct you to VT State Police.
Short hotel trips under 10 straight days and under 30 total days per year generally do not trigger VT registration.
Your home state may still require advance travel notice; follow those rules too.
Vermont has no statewide residency ban; supervision can add case-by-case limits while you are on probation or parole.
